content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim">    <dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:invenio="http://invenio-software.org/elements/1.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:identifier>doi:10.5281/zenodo.15638</dc:identifier><dc:creator>Zipser, Florian</dc:creator><dc:creator>Zeldes, Amir</dc:creator><dc:creator>Ritz, Julia</dc:creator><dc:creator>Romary, Laurent</dc:creator><dc:creator>Leser, Ulf</dc:creator><dc:title>Pepper: Handling a multiverse of formats</dc:title><dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject><dc:description><p>With the rising importance of empirical data in many fields of linguistic research, we see an<br /> increase not only in the amount of electronically available corpora, but also in the number of<br /> tools used to make this data accessible, processable and searchable. Most of these tools have<br /> been developed in the course of specific linguistic projects and therefore can only handle a<br /> certain kinds of linguistic information, such as syntactic-structures (e.g. TIGERSearch, Lezius<br /> 2002), or dialogue-structures (e.g. EXMARaLDA, Schmidt 2004) etc. At the same time, each<br /> tool uses its own, proprietary format for representing the text and its annotations. Such<br /> formats are optimized for a specific kind of analysis and the performance of a specific<br /> processing tool. Consequently they cannot easily be mapped onto each other. This impedes<br /> those linguistic research questions which pre-suppose a global view on data, i.e., which<br /> require the option to correlate, query and analyze several kinds of linguistic annotations at<br /> once.<br /> We present Pepper, a modularized converter framework addressing the problem that a<br /> linguistic researcher may be limited to a small set of questions due to the tool(s) he or she<br /> uses. Pepper is based on the meta-model Salt (Zipser &amp; Romary 2010) and offers the<br /> possibility of converting data from n formats into m formats with a minimal number of<br /> necessary mappings. The pluggable architecture of Pepper allows the injection of new formats<br /> into the framework. Pepper has no restrictions on the underlying techniques used in<br /> representing these formats (e.g. XML, tabular-formats, bracketing-formats or mixtures<br /> thereof).</p></dc:description><dc:publisher/><dc:date>2011-02-24</dc:date><dc:source>http://zenodo.org/record/15638</dc:source><dc:doi>10.5281/zenodo.15638</dc:doi><dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/15638</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>oai:zenodo.org:15638</dc:identifier></dc:dc>   </collection>
